headline: CNN 10
subHeadline: Economy After Silicon Valley Bank Shut Down; Controversial Willow Oil Drilling Project, Most Intense Baby Race. Aired 4-4:10a ET

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Don`t look now, but there`s something funny going on over there at the bank, George. I`ve never really seen one, but that`s gotall the earmarks of being a run.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: The classic scene from, "It`s A Wonderful Life" dramatizes the panic involved in a run on thebank. It happens when there`s a loss of confidence in the bank, and that leads to large withdrawals. The bank can`t pay everyone who wants their money all at once, and it fails. During the Great Depression, thousands of banks failed 9000, to be exact, taking $7 billion worth of customers assets with them. That`s why the new deal included laws to ensure deposits and boost confidence in financial institutions. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the FDIC, was created in 1933, and today covers up to $250,000 per depositor at FDIC insured banks. Actual bank failures still happen. There were a lot during the Great Financial Crisis in 2008, but in recent years, just a handful every year, and none in 2021 and 2022. That streak broke in March of 2023, Silicon Valley Bank, a prominent lender to tech startups, collapsed after questions about its liquidity started piling up. That caused customers to start withdrawing their money, essentially sparking a run on the bank. When SVB couldn`t raise enough capital to cover customer demand, regulators stepped in and took control of the bank. The danger with a bank run is that panic can spread to other banks. It`s called contagion.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Day one, there were two people, and then four, and then 16. In three months, it`s a billion. That`s where we`re headed.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: So what starts as a problem at a single bank can quickly turn into a crisis for the entire system. That`s what happened during the GreatFinancial Crisis in 2008. And it`s why the collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the second largest U.S. bank failure of all time, has Wall Street on edge. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Ten second trivia.In 1867, the U.S. bought what 600,000 square mile territory for less than two cents per acre? Louisiana, Alaska, Florida or Texas? Now the largest state in the U.S., Alaska is bigger than Texas, California, and Montana combined. And up next, we`re headed to Alaska where this week the Biden administration approved a controversial oil drilling project called the ConocoPhillips Willow Project. The move is making some climate advocates angry and could set the stage for a court challenge in the future. The project is a decades long oil drilling venture in the National Petroleum Reserve on the north shore of Alaska, which is owned by the federal government. The planned site holds up to 600 million barrels of oil. The approval is considered a victory for Alaska`s government and a coalition of native tribes who feel the drilling venture is a much-needed new source of revenue and jobs for this remote region. But climate groups and some Alaska natives argue that the project will hurt the country`s climate goals and pose health and environmental risks. We`ll hear now from CNN National Correspondent Rene Marsh who has more. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: At this point, the only way that this project can be stopped is if --

utterances.speaker: RENE MARSH, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: On TikTok and Instagram calls for President Biden to stop Willow Project. An urgent call that`s gone viral toblock a controversial Alaska oil drilling project.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Please help stop Willow.

utterances.speaker: MARSH
utterances.sentences: The videos ranking up tens of millions of views, spurring more a million letters to the White House and more than 3 million signatures to achange.org petition.

utterances.speaker: ELISE JOSHI, GENZ FOR CHANGE
utterances.sentences: In order to stop Willow, people need to know about Willow.

utterances.speaker: MARSH
utterances.sentences: 20-year-old Elise Joshi, a senior at the University of California, Berkeley, is one of the social media activists.

utterances.speaker: JOSHI
utterances.sentences: -- will not just impact Alaska, it will not just impact this country, it will impact the world. But the amount of carbon emissions thatit will emit, we will see an increase in frequency and intensity of natural disasters.

utterances.speaker: MARSH
utterances.sentences: ConocoPhillips Willow Project would be located in northwest Alaska on the National Petroleum Reserve, federal land roughly the size ofIndiana. The project would tap as much as 600 million barrels of oil, but it would take years for it to make it to market. Its messy politics for President Biden, pitting his climate promises against the desire to produce energy at home and lower gas prices. Nagruk Harcharek`s family has also lived in the region for generations. He supports the project. His nonprofit represents two dozen native communities, corporations and local governments who say the project would be an economic boon and help the U.S. wean off of foreign oil.

utterances.speaker: NAGRUK HARCHAREK, THE VOICE OF THE ARCTIC INUPIAT
utterances.sentences: The economics that a project like this would bring into the region, mainly to the North Slopeborough in the form of taxes, to help provide and maintain first world conditions. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: WIRE
utterances.sentences: Let`s head on over to North Carolina, where there is some heated competition at the halftime of a Tar Heels basketball game. A race calledDiapers to Dorms Dash. Adorable babies crawling towards their parents, waiting at the finish line for a chance at winning $529 for their education fund. Bring it on, baby. Our Jeanne Moos is on the call. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: JEANNE MOOS, CNN NATIONAL NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: It was a baby race that had pulses racing. Parents were psyched.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hi Lyla.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Babies were wide eyed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Crawl babies, crawl.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: And thereof, it was half time at a University of North Carolina basketball game. Lyla instantly took the lead. Continued towards someoneelse`s mom instead of her dad.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: But she`s going to another parent. Lyla`s going to a different house.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Lyla was so, so stinking cute.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: And that`s coming from one of Lyla`s rivals. Lyla made it just inches from the finish but stopped dead despite pleas from the announcer.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Lyla, please. Please, just touch it.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Another contestant made his move to pass. Lyla then plopped down, even bopped a bit, and finally turned the wrong way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: No, no, no.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Wonder some considered this the most intense baby race ever. And then Lyla did the unthinkable. And just as she reversed course, a darkhorse entered the fray. (On camera): Is she a fast crawler?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Well, funny enough is she only started crawling maybe a week, week and a half before that baby race.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: Nine-month-old Brexley Dennick`s (ph) strategy was to start slow. So slow, her dad had to throw his watch down the court and hope she`d follow.It worked. And once Brexley got going --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: She doesn`t give up, which is great, and I hope she can keep doing that for the rest of her life.

utterances.speaker: MOOS
utterances.sentences: To lure her over the finish, Brexley`s mom did what most of the other parents tried waving the phone.All that crawling earned the winner a $529 check for her future education fund. But this was its an education on how we`re all doomed to end up on our knees looking for our phones for the rest of our lives. (END VIDEOTAPE)
